Comment: I went with the e4 opening.  Since I know how to play against the Sicilian with c3, I don't shy away from e4 any more.
King's Pawn Opening.
I developed, attacking the pawn.  I didn't have a clear strategy yet, just developing.
Continued development.

I thought this would be a perfect little spot for my Bishop along the a2-g8 diagonal.  I was eyeing down on that f7 square.  At this point I thought if I could get my Queen over, I could form a pretty successful attack on the King side.
Adding an attacker on the d5 square.
Adding another defender on the d5 square.  Now, 4. Nc3 d5 5. exd5 Nxd5 6. Nxd5(or Bxd5) ... and I have successfully defended against the attack.
Further development.
Eliminating the possibility of a Bg4 pin.

Now that he castled I knew his King was going to stay there, so I can begin my assault.  First, I open up my Bishop to get involved.  I was weary of closing off my light square Bishop from joining the attack, but it was already involved by putting pressure on the f7 square.

Now that he castled I knew his King was going to stay there, so I can begin my assault.  First, I open up my Bishop to get involved.  I was weary of closing off my light square Bishop from joining the attack, but it was already involved by putting pressure on the f7 square.
I believe this was an attempt to form an attack.  It opened up the way for his Bishop to come over.

Now I saw the possible benefits of having my Bishop and Queen on the same diagonal.  I believe I was considering 8. Qd2 ... 9. Bg4 Bxg4, then I could either exchange Queens or accept the extra Bishop, but a better opportunity arose...

...With this move.  I could see he was looking to trap me into 8. Nxh4 Qxh4, and he would have an active Queen on the King side.  So, I continued my attack preparations hoping he would hold off on Bxf2.
I think this rather halted the proposition of Bxf2, since it would now give me the opportunity to bring my Queen over.
Now I take the Bishop, since after 9. Nxh4 Qxh4 10. Bh5 ... his Queen is trapped.
Now I take the Bishop, since after 9. Nxh4 Qxh4 10. Bh5 ... his Queen is trapped.
Now he falls into my trap.
Traps the Queen and serves the dual purpose of forming the attack that I'd wanted from the beginning.
I liked this move.  I was expecting Qxg5.  I couldn't take the Knight because fxg3 would lead to Qxg3 and he would preserve his Queen.
Now the sequence is finished.  After Nxh1, O-O-O traps his Knight.
Bingo.  He can't preserve the Knight, either.
Bingo.  He can't preserve the Knight, either.
